Hey! i have two questions that i asked myself when i saw 'Interstellar';

1.
The moment when the crew of the Endurance lands on the planet near "Gargantua", One hour on that planet would be seven years back on earth. I wondered myself, If there was a telescope on that planet (hypothetical) that could zoom in so far that it could see earth. What would they see? A rapid version of earthly evolution? eventually a destruction of earths life by a mass extinction? Will time ever catch up?... So many questions!

2.
Near the ending of the movie, Cooper goes into a '3Dimensionalized' version of the 5th dimension. Cooper looks into Murphs room and bangs the bookshelf. Later there was explained that the whole event is a loop in space time...
The question is thus: did the loop ever started? and how did it start? Since we now time had a beginning and an ending... The loop should had a beginning to, right?

Not really ASAPquestions but i hope you are enthusiastic about this ones ;)

This is a joke! Multicellular life, as we know it, exists since about half a billion years. In the meantime our ancestors evolved from worms to fish, came out of the water, separated into dinosaurs/birds and mammals, some of them managed to fly, several groups changed from quadrupeds to bipeds and some of their descendants from bipeds back to being quadrupeds. Others went back into the water. Humanity is just a flyspeck in evolution, compared to all this. Then think back 4.5 billion years to the beginning of our planet. Why would we assume, human beings would still exist in 5 billion years? Why would we even expect mammals to be left in just 1 billion years? If there will be life still on earth in 1 billion years from now, it must look totally different from what we know today! Also humans will have evolved into some way higher form of existence, which unlikely will even resemble a typical mammal! Really, this world is not static, although many people want it to be static.

What I propose is a way we can a) escape from the sun and b) save ourselves from human seen destruction. It is the idea of an interstellar ark, if you will, that is made up of a massive (and I'm talking gargantuan) O'Neill cylinder that rotates around a central pole to create an artificial gravity environment, and one massive or multiple propulsion systems deemed the Bussard Ram Scoop. This uses a positive magnetic field to attract interstellar hydrogen into a sustainable fusion reaction, which propels the spacecraft. The design isn't flawless however, fusion hasn't been researched enough and we have yet to think about building something so vast, but I'm confident ten of these could contain the entire earth's population. The thing about the Sun having used up the hydrogen in its core by 1 billion years and then having to burn hydrogen on the surface by that time is false. Core hydrogen exhaustion won't happen for around 5-6 billion years.
What's actually going on around that time is as it burns hydrogen, the Sun produces helium. This gets deposited in the core, compressing it and raising the temperature. Higher temperature = greater fusion rate = increased brightness. What's significant about 1 billion years is that's when the Sun has become bright enough to vaporize the oceans...

If we want to keep Earth afloat, the easiest method would be to build giant boosters all around the equator. If each booster was to fire off for a period of 5 minutes at 6 pm within its' timezone , the perpendicular thrust  would gradually increase earth's overall velocity, which would in turn increase Earth's orbit.

The thrust of each booster engine would not be enough to move Earth by much, but if we were to scatter, say, 6000 boosters (1 every 4-5 km or so), and each would fire off every 5 minutes with a strong enough force, we could in theory accelerate earth AND maintain its' rotation.

If Juno can really manage to pull off the nearly impossible task of studying Jupiter's "core", that should be considered the greatest finding in history, assuming we still don't find any sign of ET. Anywho, the "core" of Jupiter is a scary, scary place; almost, if not just as, mysterious as black holes. It's so tense and hot there that even atoms like hydrogen become metallic and begin conducting electricity (thus producing Jupiter's huge magnetic field that extends all the way to Saturn). Overpopulation isn't really the doomsday scenario people make it out to to be. All populations have a limit in size that they can maintain while still being healthy called the carrying capacity. When they exceed it, things called "density dependent mortality factors" (like plagues, lack of food, etc.) begin to kill off portions of the population until it goes back down under that capacity. From there, we'll prosper for a little while with out new slightly smaller population and repeat the cycle.

Color just has to do with wavelengths of waves. There's a visible range of waves, and an invisible spectrum. Most waves (x-rays, infrared, radio waves, etc...) are part of this invisible range so we can't see them, but we can see some (the colors) because they're at the right wavelength. So no, a new color can't just be invented, there's only a small range of wavelengths which we can see.

The sun won't fuse hydrogen at its surface after 1B years.  The concentration of hydrogen in the core is slowly falling, so the core has to collapse further in on itself and raise its temperature to keep everything in balance.  This higher temperature causes its outer layers to "puff out" and the increased surface area (along with a warming core) cause the sun to increase in luminosity.  Eventually the core gets so hot, it starts fusing helium...then we're REALLY screwed!

BTW, the fusion isn't happening on the surface, rather, the start of the red giant phase is predicated by a contraction that moves some of the remaining surface hydrogen deep into the core layers.  This compression results in additional heat which increases the rate of P-P fusion, thus kicking off the red giant phase.  It will then move onto the triple alpha process after that hydrogen injection is consumed, and that begins the true red giant phase.  Just adding this for clarity, cheers!
